sen.j: 山崎 闇斎（やまざき あんさい、元和 (日本)4年12月9日 (旧暦)（1619年1月24日） - 天和 (日本)2年9月16日 (旧暦)（1682年10月16日））は、江戸前期の儒者・朱子学者・神道家・思想家。
sen.e: Ansai YAMAZAKI (January 24, 1619 - October 16, 1682) was a Confucian scholar, neo-Confucian Scholar, Shintoist and thinker in the early Edo period.
sen.cmt: 江戸前期→the early Edo period (based on ALC)
sen.e: Ansai YAMAZAKI (January 24, 1619 - October 16, 1682) was a Confucian scholar, neo-Confucian scholar, Shintoist and philosopher of the early Edo period.
sen.cmt: While "思想家" and "哲学者" are not quite the same thing, "thinker" seems strange to me without some kind of adjective indicating what kind of thinker he was (e.g. political thinker).
sen.e: Ansai YAMAZAKI (January 24, 1619 - October 16, 1682) was a Confucian scholar, neo-Confucian scholar, Shintoist and philosopher of the early Edo period.

sen.j: 名は嘉、字は敬義、通称嘉右衛門。
sen.e: While he was known as Uemon KA, his name was KA and his nickname was Moriyoshi.

sen.j: 闇斎は号、霊社号は垂加霊社 (すいか・しでます)。
sen.e: He was given the name Ansai as his go (byname) and Suika (Shidemasu)-Reisha as Reisha-Go.
He was given the name Ansai as Confucian scholar Go (title) and Suika-Shidemasu as Reisha (an architecture where a small shrine to warship ancestors' spirits is placed)-Go.
sen.cmt: There is too much Japanese in this translation for a native speaker to have any chance of understanding this. I've fixed a little of it but it really needs to be re-translated. Certainly the term "reisha-go" needs to be accompanied by an explanation and I'm not sure if "byname" is an appropriate explanation of "go".(translator note)Reisha is a place or building where "Shoushi" (a small shrine) to warship ancestors' spirits is placed and often near the family grave yard or familiar place.祖先の霊を祀るために墓所や縁故の場所に小祠を設けたものを霊社儒者号を闇斎、神道号を垂加（すいか）と称した。http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E5%B1%B1%E5%B4%8E%E9%97%87%E6%96%8E/Idea of "Shoushi" can be obtained from the following: the http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110004654715/
sen.e: He was given the name Ansai as Confucian scholar Go (title) and Suika (also called Shidemasu) -Reisha as Reisha-Go (Shintoist title).
sen.cmt: 原文の「すいか・しでます」は、「垂加」の読みが「すいか」「しでます」の2つあるという意味のため、Suika-Shidemasu→Suika (also called Shidemasu) -Reishaとし、後に続く補足を削除、および「霊社号」→「神道号」と解釈し、Reisha-Go (Shintoist title)としました。(参照: http://100.yahoo.co.jp/detail/%E5%B1%B1%E5%B4%8E%E9%97%87%E6%96%8E/)

sen.e: Born to a Ronin (Samurai) family in Kyoto, he entered Hieizan mountain at his young age and moved to Myoshin-ji Temple to become a monk.
Born to a ronin (masterless samurai) family in Kyoto, he left home for Mt. Hiei at a young age to enter the Myoshin-ji Temple and become a monk.

sen.e: When he was about nineteen years old, he moved to Gyuko-ji Temple in Tosa to go apprentice under Soke SHONAN.

sen.j: 土佐南学派の谷時中から朱子学の手ほどきを受け、また野中兼山や小倉三省らとの交わりのなかで、朱子学への傾倒を深め、1642年に還俗して儒者となった。
sen.e: While he was having Neo-Confucian training from Jichu TANI in the Tosa-Namgakuha, he grew seriously involved in the Neo-Confucian from socializing with Kenzan NONAKA and Sansei OGURA, and accomplished an exclaustration to become a New-Confucian in 1642.

He had Neo-Confucian training from Jichu TANI in the Tosa-Namgakuha. He became seriously involved in Neo-Confucianism from his association with Kenzan NONAKA and Sansei OGURA, and accomplished an exclaustration to become a New-Confucian in 1642.

He had Neo-Confucian training from Jichu TANI in the Tosa Nangaku school, and he became seriously involved in Neo-Confucianism from his association with Kenzan NONAKA and Sansei OGURA, and accomplished an exclaustration to become a New-Confucian in 1642.
sen.cmt: 訳文が二文に分かれているため一文になるよう修正、Tosa-Namgakuha→Tosa Nangaku schoolに修正

sen.j: 1665年、会津藩主保科正之の賓師に迎えられ、藩政への助言者として活躍する。
sen.e: He was invited to work as a Hinshi for the lord of Aizu, Masayuki HOSHINA in 1665 and took an active role to give advice about the ruling in the domain.
He was invited to work as a Hinshi for the lord of Aizu, Masayuki HOSHINA in 1665; and, took an active role in giving advice on the ruling of the domain.
He was invited to work as a Hinshi (guest teacher) for the lord of Aizu, Masayuki HOSHINA in 1665; and, took an active role in giving advice on the ruling of the domain.

sen.j: 領内の寺院・神社の整理をおこない、神仏習合を排除した。
sen.e: He reorganized temples and shrines in his territory to rule out the syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism.
He reorganized temples and shrines in his territory to rule out the syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism.

sen.j: また吉川惟足の影響で、神道研究にも本格的に取り組むようになった。
sen.e: Influenced by Koretari YOSHIKAWA, he also got to be seriously involved in Shinto research.

sen.e: The Neo-Confucian advocated by him is called Kimon-gaku or Ansai-gaku.

sen.j: 従来の神道と儒学を統合して、垂加神道を開いた。
sen.e: He integrated the former Shinto and Neo-Confucian to set up the foundation of the Suika-Shinto.
He integrated traditional Shinto with Neo-Confucianism, and laid the foundation for Suika-Shinto.

sen.j: その思想の独自性は、放伐を否定した点にあり、水戸学・国学などとともに、幕末の尊王攘夷思想に大きな影響を与えた。
sen.e: Distinctive character of his philosophy was to deny Hobatsu (expel outrageous tyrants, etc. from a capital), and this had significant influence on the Sonno-Joi (Revere the Emperor and expel the foreigners) in the end of the Edo Period as well as Mito-gaku and Koku-gaku.
sen.cmt: 放伐の英訳に下を括弧書きで追加しました。Expel outrageous tyrants, etc. from a capital.
sen.e: The distinctive character of his philosophy was the denial of Hobatsu (expel outrageous tyrants, etc. from a capital), and this had significant influence on the Sonno-Joi (Revere the Emperor and expel the foreigners) at the end of the Edo Period, as well as for Mito-gaku and Koku-gaku.
